frameDefinitions: A Speaker conventionally uses a particular Term to refer to an Entity.
A Speaker uses a particular linguistic form, a Name to refer to an Entity.
A Speaker uses as a Label to refer to an Entity.
A Captor ends the captivity or inhibition of the motion of a Theme from the Location_of_confinement.
This frame concerns entities conventionally being referred to by particular names.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
frameExamples: The pattern of conservation is similar to that found in C1_1, therefore we have <t>termed</t> this domain DC1 for divergent C1 domain.
They corresponded frequently and at length, exchanging intimate letters in which he <t>addressed</t> her as Windflower.
They <t>released</t> me from prison on New Year's Day.
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
listRoleDefinitions: The type of <fen>Entity</fen> that is conventionally referred to by a <fen>Term</fen>.
The linguistic sign that is used for referring to a type of <fen>Entity</fen>.
The speaker or speech community that uses a <fen>Term</fen> to refer to a particular <fen>Entity</fen>.
The person who uses the <fen>Name</fen>  to refer to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The entity that is designated by the <fen>Speaker</fen> with the <fen>Name</fen> used.
The linguistic form used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to refer to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The point of time or interval when the <fen>Speaker</fen> uses the <fen>Name</fen>.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person who conventionally uses a linguistic sign to refer to an <fen>Entity</fen>.
The concrete or abstract thing with which the <fen>Speaker</fen> has associated a particular linguistic sign.
The linguistic sign that the <fen>Speaker</fen> uses to designate the <fen>Entity</fen>.
A text whose author applies a particular <fen>Label</fen> to an <fen>Entity</fen>.
A time period in which a <fen>Speaker</fen> uses the <fen>Label</fen>.
A physical space whose occupants use the <fen>Label</fen> to refer to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Captor</fen> is the individual who ends the confinement or captivity of the <fen>Theme</fen>. The release of the <fen>Theme</fen> is in accord with the plans of the <fen>Captor</fen>.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the person or object in motion released by the <fen>Captor</fen>.
The location to which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s motion was formerly inhibited.
The <fen>Time</fen> identifies when the <fen>Captor</fen> release the <fen>Theme</fen> .
The location where the <fen>Theme</fen> ceases to be confined.
<fen>Name</fen> identifies the linguistic expression used to refer to Entities.
The <fen>Entity</fen> is the person the speaker intends to refer to by using a particular name.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
listRoleExamples: Because of that shift, physicists call <fex>this effect</fex> the 'gravitational red shift.'
The French term this plant <fex>Petit Chêne</fex>, from the shape of the leaves.
<fex>Mathematicians</fex> call this subject 'arithmetic,' reserving the word 'algebra' for the more advanced aspects of the subject.
<fex>The Lord, who was charmed by her beauty,</fex> addressed her as 'than kaadhali!' (My darling) and hence the name.
And that's the reason why we called <fex>him</fex> 'Tom' when his real name was actually John.
A male voice answered the call, and Jones addressed the man as <fex>'Johnny.'</fex>
No one had <fex>ever</fex> called her 'my lady'.
<fex>They</fex> call it a Mutt Mitt.

He termed <fex>it</fex> 'a pretty incredible discovery' on par with two other 10,000-
to 11,000-year-old specimens
In Texas, we call it <fex>walking'</fex>.
<fex>Your article</fex> labels him 'Republican Senator Jim Exon'.
<fex>Back in the olden days</fex>, they called it 'Bohemian people.'
I really loved this movie. <fex>In France</fex>, they called it 'Turbo Interceptor'.
<fex>The police</fex> released the suspect.
The police released <fex>the suspect</fex>.
She petitioned unsuccessfully for their release <fex>from Chateau D'If</fex>.
'Aren't you going to release us <fex>here</fex>?' she asked.
My name is <fex>Bond</fex>.
<fex>You</fex> have an unusual surname.
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
